entry.title: Combined summary - Bitcoin Core 0.10 release schedule
entry.summary: Bitcoin Core developers are planning to release version 0.10 of the software by January 2015, with a branch split-off and feature freeze planned for November 18, 2014. The final release date will depend on how long it takes to resolve any critical issues found during the release candidate cycle. Major developments that have already been proposed, such as BIP62 and the verification library, need to be merged before November 18. Other potential features that may make it into the release include Gitian descriptors overhaul, "autoprune," an "RPC warmup mode," and an unauthenticated HTTP REST interface.On October 26, 2014, Wladimir proposed a plan for the release of Bitcoin 0.10, suggesting splitting off a 0.10 branch on November 18th and releasing 10.0rc1 on December 1st to start the Release Candidate cycle. The RC cycle would run until no critical problems are found, with the final release expected no later than January 2015. Additionally, he suggested switching to a fixed six-month major release schedule starting in July 2015 with 0.11.0.In the context, there is a follow-up question on Github related to current dust change handling, mentioning a query related to floating fees for Core 0.10. Wladimir responds by confirming that floating/smart fees have been merged a while ago via two links provided in the context.Melvin Carvalho suggested creating a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) to put forth ideas and proposals. The new REST interface is seen as a good starting point for further discussion. There are plans to add last-modified and etag headers. Additionally, there are proposals to export UTXOs and to rebuild the RPC server to something multithreaded. Jeff Garzik is a Bitcoin core developer and open-source evangelist at BitPay Inc. A link to PR #2844 can be found at https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/2844.Luke Dashjr also reached out to Wladimir, asking for his opinion on what is ready and not too risky to be included in version 0.10. Luke suggested introducing CNodePolicy for putting isolated node policy code and proposed harmless changes. The miners requested enabling customization of node policy for data carrier data size with a low-risk configuration change. Wladimir approved all the changes except for the full-blown "miner policy class," which he thought was best to wait for version 0.11.In another email conversation, Melvin Carvalho asked for documentation on the REST API for electronic coins. Wladimir referred him to the opening post from Jeff Garzik, which contained some documentation on using the API. Melvin also asked about the stability of version one of the API going forward and whether or not there would be support to develop this interface into something that would be W3C standards compliant. Wladimir responded that it wasn't too late to change the URI, and while a W3C standard takes a long time to come through, it may be more useful to have the API available rather than wait for standardization. They are only interested in exposing read-only public data already available in Bitcoin Core's internals.Developers can help with the development process by testing and reviewing pull requests, as well as reporting bugs and regressions.
